title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not describe how human activities could have increased the amount of sediment in stream 2 as when the area was clear-cut, the trees no longer hold the soil/sediment and it can be carried into stream 2.

The response describes how human activities could have increased the amount of sediment in stream 2 as when the area was clear-cut, the trees no longer hold the soil/sediment and it can be carried into stream 2.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the risk of flooding is greater near stream 2 than near stream 1, such as any of the following:

· Stream 2 is near a forest that was clear-cut, which leads to an increase in flooding because there are fewer trees/tree roots near Stream 2 to hold down soil/absorb water/slow down runoff during a rain event.

· Stream 2 is near a forest that was clear-cut, which leads to increased flooding during a rain event because the soil is compacted (decreased porosity).

The response explains why the risk of flooding is greater near stream 2 than near stream 1, such as one of the following:

· Stream 2 is near a forest that was clear-cut, which leads to an increase in flooding because there are fewer trees/tree roots near Stream 2 to hold down soil/absorb water/slow down runoff during a rain event.

· Stream 2 is near a forest that was clear-cut, which leads to increased flooding during a rain event because the soil is compacted (decreased porosity).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence based on the diagram that a regulating ecosystem service has been devalued as a result of human activities, such as any of the following:

· Trees were clear cut, which devalues their service to a provisioning ecosystem service, such as:

o timber or lumber

o storing water

o providing natural products for medicinal use

· Increased sediments and metal contamination of the lake from logging and mining devalues its service of providing drinking water.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why soil forming over a volcanic rock might differ from soil forming over a different type of bedrock, such as sandstone or limestone, such as any of the following:

· Soils form over limestone would have better buffering capacity than soils formed over volcanic rock because limestone contains calcium carbonate, which reduces changes to pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbbjxAHX garmWu51MyVXgaruWqVvNCPvMCG4uz3bqefqvATv2CG4uz3bIuV1wy Ubqee0evGueE0jxyaibaieYlf9irVeeu0dXdh9vqqj=hEeeu0xXdbb a9frFj0=OqFfea0dXdd9vqaq=JfrVkFHe9pgea0dXdar=Jb9hs0dXd bPYxe9vr0=vr0=vqpWqaaeaabiGaciaacaqabeaadaabauaaaOqaaa baaaaaaaaapeGaaeiCaiaabIeaaaa@39D7@ /has minerals that react with acids.

· Soils form over volcanic rock would have higher fertility/nutrient content.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that support or opposes the miners’ assertion that the area in which the ore is being mined must have been located at a divergent plate boundary, such as any of the following:

· The miners’ assertion could be supported because volcanic activity may occur at divergent plate boundaries.

· The miners’ assertion could be opposed because volcanic activity may occur at convergent plate boundaries, so the boundary does not have to be a divergent plate boundary.

title: Part G
